titleStmt.title: A vvoman is a vveather-cocke. A new comedy, as it was acted before the King in White-Hall. And diuers times priuately at the White-Friers, by the Children of her Maiesties Reuels. Written by Nat: Field.
Woman is a weather-cocke
Woman is a weather-cocke.
Woman's a wether-cocke.
titleStmt.author: Field, Nathan, 1587-1620?

publicationStmt.publisher: [By William Jaggard] for Iohn Budge, and are to be sold at the gteat [sic] south doore of Paules, and at Brittaines Bursse,

note.p: Running title reads: A woman's a wether-cocke.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: A Woman is Weather-cocke. A New Comedy, As it was acted before the King in WHITE-HALL. And diuers times Priuately at the White-Friers, By the Children of her Maiesties Reuels.

quote.l: Si natura negat faciat Indagnatio versum.

div.p: Printed at London, for Iohn Budge, and are to be sold at the great South doore of Paules, and at Brittaines Bursse. 1612.

div.head: To any Woman that hath beene no Weather Cocke.
div.p: I Did determine, not to haue Dedicated my Play to any Body, because forty shillings I care not for, and aboue, few or none will bestowe on these matters, especially falling from so famelesse a pen as mine is yet. And now I looke vp, and finde to whom my Dedication is, I feare I am as good as my determination: notwithstanding I leaue a libertie to any Lady or woman, that dares say she hath beene no weather-Cocke, to assume the Title of Patronesse to this my Booke. If she haue beene constant, and be so, all I will expect from her for my paynes, is, that she will continue so, but till my next Play be printed, wherein she shall see what amendes I haue made to her, and all the sex, and so I end my Epistle, without a Latine sentence.

div.head: To the Reader
div.p: REader, the Sale-man sweares, youle take it very ill, if I say not somewhat to you too, Introth you are a stranger to me; why should I Write to you? you neuer writ to mee, nor I thinke will not answere my Epistle. I send a Comedie to you heer, as good as I could then make; nor sleight my presentation, because it is a play: For I tell thee Reader, if thou bee'st ignoraunt, a Play is not so ydle a thing as thou art, but a Mirrour of mens Liues and actions now, be it perfect or imperfect, true or false, is the Vice or Vertue of the Maker. This is yet, as well, as I can, Qualeis ego vel Cluuienus, Thou must needs haue some other Language then thy Mother rong, for thou thinkst it impossible for me to write a Play that did not vse a word of Latine, though he had enough in him. I haue beene vexed with vile playes my selfe, a great while, hearing many, nowe I thought to be euen with some, and they shoulde heare mine too. Fare thee well, if thou hast any thing to say to me, thou know'st where to heare of me for a yeare or two, and no more I assure thee.

div.head: To his Loued Sonne, Nat. Field, and his Wether-cocke Woman.
div.l: TO many formes, as well as many waies,
Thy Actiue Muse, turnes like thy Acted woman:
In which, disprais'd inconstancie, turnes praise;
Th' Addition being, and grace of Homers Sea-man,
In this life's rough Seas tost, yet still the same:
So turns thy wit, Inconstancy to stay,
And stay t' Inconstancy: And as swift Fame
Growes as she goes, in Fame so thriue thy Play,
And thus to standing, turne thy womans fall,
Wit turn'd to euerie thing, prooues stay in all.

div.head: scen. prima.
div.stage: Enter Scudmore, as in his Chamber in a morning, halfe ready, reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sc. Legit.
sp.l: WHereas you write, my fortunes and my birth
Made aboue yours, may be a reall cause
That I must leaue you, know thou worthiest man,
Thou hast a soule, whose plenteous wealth supplies
All the leane wants blinde Chance hath dealt to thee.
Yet could I thinke, the Goddes from all their store,
Who ne're knew indigence vnto their will,
Would (out of all their stocke of Vertue left,
Or out of all new graces they can make)
Make such another peece as Scudmore is,
Then might he iustly feare; but otherwise,
Sooner the Masculine Element of Fire,
Shall flame his Pyramids downe to the Earth;
Sooner her Mountaines shall swell vp to Heauen;
Or softest Aprill showers quench fires in Hell;
Sooner shall Starres from this Circumference,
Drop like false fierie exhalation,
Then I be false to vowes made vnto thee;
In whom, ought ne're a fault: I ne're could see,
But that you doubted once my constancie.

div.stage: Yours through the world, and to the end of Time. Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Scud. Loqui, ve raptus.
sp.l: If (what I feele) I could expresse in words,
Methinkes I could speake ioy enough to men,
To banish sadnesse from all loue, foreuer:
Oh thou that reconcil'st the faults of all
That froathy sex, and in thy single selfe
Confin'st, nay hast engrost Vertue enough
To frame a spacious world of vertuous women;
Hadst thou bin the Beginning of thy sex.
I thinke the Deuill in the Serpents skin,
Had wanted Cunning to orecome thy goodnesse,
And all had liu'd and dy'de in Innocency
The white Originall Creation. Knockes within.
Whos's there? Come in.

div.stage: Enter Neuill.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: What, vp already Scudmore, neare a Wench with thee? Not thy Laundresse?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Good-morrow my deare Neuill.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: What's this? A Letter; Sure it is not so,
A Letter written to Hieronimo!

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: By Heauen you must excuse me; Come, I know
You will not wrong my friendship and your manners to tempt me so.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Not for the world my friend,
Farewell, Good-morrow. Exiturus.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Nay Sir, Neither must you
Depart in anger from this friendly hand:
I sweare, I loue you better then all men,
Equally with all Vertue in the world:
Yet this would be a Key to lead you to
A prize of that importance.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Worthy friend,
I leaue you not in anger: What de'e meane?
Nor am I of that inquisitiue Nature fram'd,
To thirst to know your priuate businesses:
Why, they concerne not me; If they be ill
And dangerous, t'would greeue me much to know em.
If good; they be so, though I know em not:
Nor would I do your loue so grosse a wrong,
To Couet, to participate affaires
Of that neere touch, which your assured loue
Doth thinke not fit, or dares not trust me with.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: How sweetly does your friendship play with mine,
And with a simple subtilty, steales my heart
Out of my bosome. By the holiest Loue
That euer made a Story, y'are a man
With all good so repleate, that I durst trust you
Euen with this secret, were it singly mine.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: I do beleeue you, farewell worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Nay looke you, this same fashion does not please me,
You were not wont to make your visitation.
So short and carelesse.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Tis your Iealousie
That makes you thinke it so, for by my soule
You have giuen me no distast, in keeping from me
All things that might be burthenous, and oppresse me.
In troth I am inuited to a wedding,
And the Morne faster goes away from me,
Then I go toward it: and so Good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: God-morrow Sir, thinke I durst shew it you.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Now by my life I not desire it Sir,
Nor euer lou'd these prying listening men,
That aske of other states and passages,
Not one among a hundered but proues false,
Enuious and slanderous, and wil cut that throat
He twines his armes about, I loue that Poet
That gaue vs reading, not to seeke our selues
Beyond our selues, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: You shall not go,
I cannot now redeeme the fault I haue made
To such a friend, but in disclosing all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Now if you loue me, do not wrong me so,
I see you labour with some serious thing,
And thinke (like Fayries Treasure) to reueale it,
Will cause it vanish; and yet to conceale it
Will burst your breast, tis so delicious,
And so much greater then the Continent.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.l: Oh you haue pierc't my entrails with your words.
And I must now explaine all to your eies,
Read, and be happy in my happinesse.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Yet thinke on't, keepe thy secret, and thy friend
Sure and entire; Oh! giue not me the meanes
To become false hereafter; or thy selfe
A probable reason to distrust thy friend,
Though he be neare so true, I will not see't.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: I die by Heauen, if you denie againe,
I starue for Counsell; take it, looke vpon it;
If you do not, It is an aequall plague,
As if it had beene knowne and published:
For God-sake read, but with this Caution,
By this right hand, by this yet vnstain'd sword,
Were you my father flowing in these waues,
Or a deare sonne exhausted out of them,
Should you betray this soule of all my hopes,
Like the two brethren (though loue made em Starres)
We must be neuer more seene both againe.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: I read it fearelesse of the forfeiture,
Yet warne you, be as Cautelous, not to wound
My integritie, with doubt, on likelyhoods,
From misreport, but first exquire the Truth.

div.stage: Legit. Ne. Scud. aliquando respiciens.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Read, whilst I tell the Storie of my loue,
And sound the Truth of her heroicke Spirit,
Whom eloquence could neuer flatter yet,
Nor the best tongue of praises reach vnto.
The Maide there nam'd, I met once on a Greene
Neere to her Fathers house, me thought she show'd,
For I did looke on her, indeed no eie
That ow'd a sensible member, but must dwell
Awhile on such an object.
The passing Horses, and the feeding Kine
Stood still, and left their iournies and their food,
The singing Birds were in contention
Which should light neerest her; for her cleare eies
Deceiu'd euen men, they were so like bright skies.
Neere in a Riuolet, swum two beauteous Swans,
Whiter then any thing, but her necke and hands,
Which they left straight to comfort her: A Bull
Being baiting on the Greene for the Swaines sport,
She walking toward it, the vex'd sauage beast
Ceast bellowing; the snarling Dogges were mute,
And had enough to do to looke on her,
Whose face brought Concord, and an end of iarres,
Though Nature made em euer to haue warres.
Had there bin Beares and Lyons, when she spake
They had bin charmed too: For Graecians Lute
Was rusticke Musicke to her heauenly tongue,
Whose sweetness e'ne cast slumbers on mine eies,
Soft as Content, yet would not let me sleepe.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Yours through the world, & to the end of time. Bellafront.
Which, Bellafront Rich, Sir Iohn Wordlies Daughter?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: She is the food, the sleepe, the aire I liue by.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Oh heauen! we speake like Goddes, and do like Dogges.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Whar meanes my

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: This day, this Bellafront the Rich Heire,
Is married vnto Count Fredericke,
And that's the wedding I was going to.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I prethie do not mocke me, Married?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: It is no matter to be plaid withall,
But euen as true as women all are false.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Oh! that this stroake were Thunder to my brest,
For Neuill thou hast spoake my heart in twaine,
And with the sudden whirlewind of thy breath,
Hast rauisht me out of a temperate soile,
And set me vnder the red burning Zone.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: For shame returne thy blood into thy face,
Know'st not how flight a thing a woman is?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Yes, and how serious too: Come Ile t'the Temple,
She shall not damne her selfe for want of Counsell.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Oh! prethee run not thus into the streets,
Come dresse you better, so: Ah! as thy cloaths
Are like thy mind, too much disorder'd.
How strangely is this Tide turn'd? For a world
I would not but haue cal'd heere, as I went.
Collect thy Spirits, we will vse all meanes
To checke this blacke fate, flying toward thee; Come,
If thou miscarriest, tis my day of doome.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Yes, now I'me fine, Married? It may be so,
But women looke too't, for if she proue vntrue,
The Diuell take you all, that are his due.

div.stage: Enter Count Fredericke, a Taylor trussing him, attended by a Page.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Is Sir Iohn Wordly vp, Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Is my Bride vp yet.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: No, and the Morne so faire.

div.stage: Enter Pendant.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Good morrow my thrice honor'd & heroick Lord.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good morrow your Lord and Maister you might say, for breuitie sake.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thou'ast a good Taylor, and art verie fine.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I you may thanke his Lordship indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Foregod this Dublet sits in print my Lord.
And the Hose excellent; the Pickadell rare.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Heele praise himselfe in trust with my Lords taylor,
For the next S. Georges sute.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Oh, Good-morrow Taylour, I abhorre billes in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Your Honor sayes true; their Knauerie will be discern'd by day-light,
But thou maist watch at night with bill in hand,
And no man dares finde fault with it.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: A good iest Efaith, Good-morrow to your Lordship, a verie good iest. Exit Taylor.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I wonder my inuited guests are so tardie, What's a clocke.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Scarse seauen my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: And what newes Pendant?
What think'st thou of my present marriage?
How shewes the Beautie to thee I shall wed?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why to all women, like Diana among hir Nimphs.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: There's all his reading.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A beautie of that purenesse and delight,
That none is worthy of her but my Lord,
My Honorable Lord.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: But then her fortune
Matcht with her beautie, makers her vp a match.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: By Heauen vnmatcheable, for none fit but Lords,
And yet for no Lord fit, but my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: And that her Sister then should loue me to,
Is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Strange: No, not strange at all,
By Cupid, there's no woman in the world
But must needs loue you, doate, go madde for you;
If you vouchsafe reflection; Tis a thing
That does it home: thus much reflection
Catches em vp by Dozens, like wilde foule.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Now ye shall tast the meanes by which he eates.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Nature her selfe hauing made you, fell sicke
In loue with her owne worke, and can no more
Make man so louelie, being diseasd with loue.
You are the worlds Minion, of a little man;
Ile say no more, I would not be a woman,
For all has beene got by them.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hart, I should follow you like a yong rank whore,
That runs proud for her loue, plucke you by 'th sleeue,
Who ere were with you, in the open streete,
With the impudence of a drunken Oyster-wife,
Put on my fighting wastcoate, and the Ruffe
That feares no tearing, batter downe the windowes
Where I suspected you might lie all night,
Scratch faces, like a Wilde-Cat of Pict-hatch.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Pendant thou't make me dote vpon my selfe,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Narcissus by this hand, had farre lesse cause.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: How knowst thou that?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They were all one my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How do I know, I speake my Conscience.
His beauties were but shaddowes to my Lord,
Why Boy his presence would enkindle sin,
And longing thoughts in a deuoted Nun:
Oh foote, Oh Legge, oh Hand, oh body, face,
By Ioue it is a little man of wax.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Th'art a rare Rascall; Tis not for nothing
That men call thee my Commendations.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: For nothing, no, he would be loath it should.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Poutes.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Good Morrow, and good welcome Captaine Poutes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Good Morrow to your honour, and all ioy
Spring from this match, and the first yeare a Boy,
I commend these two verses a purpose, to salute your Honor.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But how haps it Captaine, that your intended mariage with my Father in Lawes third daughter, is not solemnized to day.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My Lorde tels you true Captaine, it woulde haue sau'd meat.

div.p: Faith I know not, Mistris Kate likes me not, shee sayes I speake as if I had a pudding in my mouth, and I aunswered her, If I had it was a white pudding, and then I was the better arm'd for a woman; for I had a case about mee, so one laught, and the other cried fie: the third saide I was a Bawdy Captaine, and there was all I could get of them.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: See Boy, if they bee vp yet, Maids are long lyers I perceiue.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: How if they will not admit me my Lord:

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Why should not they admit you my Lorde, you cannot Commit with em my Lord.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Marry therefore my Lord. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But what should be the reason of her sodain alteration, she listned to thee once: Ha,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Haue you not heard my Lord, or de'e not know.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Not I, I sweare.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Then you know nothing that is worth the knowing.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: That's certaine, he knowes you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: There's a young Merchant, a late Sutor, that deals by wholesale, and Heire to Land, well descended, of worthy education, beholding to Nature.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Oh, tis young Strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ist he that lookes like an Italian Taylour? Out of the lac'd wheele, that weares a Bucket on's head?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: That is the man, yet beleeue mee Captaiue, it is a noble sprightly Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Has he money?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Infinitely wealthy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then Captaine thou art cast, would I had gon for Cleeueland; Wordly loues money better then I loue his Daughter,
sp.l: Ile to some Company in Garrison, God b'wy.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Nay, ye shall dedicate this day to me,
We speake but by the way man, nere dispaire;
I can assure you, shee's yet as free as Ayre.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And you may kill the Merchant with a looke,
I'de threaten him to death: my honor'd Lord
Shall be your friend, goe too, I say he shall,
You shall haue his good word, shall he my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sfut, he shall haue my bond to do him good.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Law, Tis the worthiest Lord in Christendome:
Oh Captaine, for some fourscore braue Spirits, once
To follow such a Lord in some attempt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A hundred Sir were better.

div.stage: Enter old Sir Innocent Ninnie, my Lady Ninnie, Sir Abraham, and Mistris Wagtayle.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Heere's more Guesse.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is that Man and Wife?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It is Sir Innocent Ninne, that's his Lady,
And that M. Abraham their onely sonne.

div.stage: Count discoursing with In: La: Abra: looking about.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But did that little, old, dri'de Neats tongue, that Eele-skin get him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: So tis said Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Methinkes, he in his Lady, should shew like a Needle in a Bottle of Hay.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: One may see by her Nose, what Pottage shee loues.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is your name Abraham; Pray who dwels in your Mothers backside, at the signe of the Aqua-vitae bottle.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Gods precious: Saue you Mistris Wagtaile.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sweet M. Pendant. Puls hir by the sleeue.

sp.speaker: S. Abr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I desire your better acquaintance, you must pardon my Father, hee's somewhat rude, rude, & my Mother grosly brought vp, as you may perceiue.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Yong M. Abraham, cry ye mercie Sir.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Your Lordships poor friend, & Sir Abra: Ninny
The Dubadub of Honor, piping hot,
Doth lye vpon my Worships shoulder blade.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord, with much cost and labour, wee haue got him Knighted; and being Knighted, vnder fauor my Lord, let me tell ye, hee'le proue a sore Knight as ere run at Ring. He is the one and onely Ninnie of our house.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: He has cost us something ere he came to his: Hold vp your head Sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Pish, pish, pish, pish.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: De'e heare how.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I had well hop'd she could not haue spoke, she is so fat.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Long maist thou wear thy Knights-hood, & thy spurs
Pricke thee to Honor on, and pricke off Curs.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Sir Abraham thankes your Honour; and I hope, your Lordship will consider the simplicity of Parents, a couple of old fooles my Lord, and I pray so take em.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I must be faine to excuse you heere, you'le needs be comming abroad with mee; if I had no more wit then you now we should be finely laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Berlady his worship saies well wise, wee'le troble him no longer; with your Honors leaue, Ile in and see my old friend Sir Iohn, your Father that shall be.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: Ile in to, and see if your Bride need no dressing.

div.stage: Exit Inno.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sfut as much as a Triple I thinke, hast them I pray. Captain, what think'st thou of such a woman in a long Sea Voyage, where there were a dearth of Victuals?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Venison my Lord, Venison.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I faith my Lord, such Venison as a Beare is.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hart, she lookes like a blacke Bumbard, with a pint pot waiting vpon it. Exeunt Lady Wag.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What Countrimen, were your Ancestors S. Abra.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Countrimen, they were no Countrimen, I scorne it, they were Gentlemen all, My Father is a Ninnie, and my Mother was a Hammer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You should be a Knocker then by the Mothers side.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I pray my Lord, what is yon Gent. he looks so like a Sarazen, that as I am a Christian I cannot endure him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Take heed what you say Sir, hee's a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: If you crosse him, hee'l blow you vp with Gunpowder

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: In good faith, he lookes as if he had had a hand in the treason, Ile take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay good Sir Abraham, you shall not leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My Lord shall be your warrant.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: My Lord shall be my warrant: Troth I doo not see that a Lords warrant is better then any other mans, vnlesse it bee to lay one by the heeles. I shall stay heere, and ha my head broake; and then I ha my mends in my owne hands, and then my Lords warrant will helpe me to a plaister, that's all.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come, come, Captaine, pray shake the hand of acquaintance with this Gentleman, he is in bodily feare of you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir, I vse not to bite any man.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, that would shew you are no Gentleman, I would you would bid me be couer'd: I am a knight, I was Knighted a purpose to come a wooing to Mistris Lucida, the middle Sister, Sir Iohn Worldlyes second daughter; and she saide she would haue mee, if I could make her a Ladie, and I can doo't now; Oh heere she comes.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Worldly, Maister Strange, Kate, and Lucida, with a Willow Garland.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: My Bride will neuer be readie I thinke: heer are the other Sisters.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Looke you my Lorde; There's Lucida weares the Willow Garland, for you; and will so go to Church I hear: and looke you Captaine, that's the Merchant.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Now doth the pot of Loue boile in my bosome; Cupid doth blow the fire; and I cannot Rime to bosome, but Ile go reason with her.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Youle make her ioynture of that fiue hundred you say, that is your inheritance, M. Strange?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Sir I will.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Kate, you do loue him?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Yes faith Father, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Take hands, kisse him, her portion is foure thousand. Good-morrow my sonne Count, you stay long for your Bride; but this is the day that sels her, and shee must come forth like my Daughter, and your Wife.
sp.l: I pray salute this Gentleman as your Brother,
This morne shall make him so; and though his habit
But speake him Cittizen, I know his worth
To be gentile in all parts. Captaine,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Captaine, I could haue beene contented well You should haue married Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: So could not Kate.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p:
You haue an honourable Title; a Souldier is a verie
honourable Title: A Captaine is a Commander of Soldiers; But look you Captaine, Captaines haue no money, therefore the Worldlies must not match with Captaines.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: So Sir, so.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: There are braue warres.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Finde them out braue Captaine,
Win honor, and get monie by that time;
Ile get a Daughter for my Noble Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Good Sir, good.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Honor is Honor, but it is no money, Aspiciens
This is the Tumbler then must catch the Coney. Strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thou'rt an old fellow: Are you a Marchant Sir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I shame not to say yes? Are you a Souldier Sir?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: A Soldier Sir; Oh God I, he is a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: He may be so, and yet no Souldier Sir: For as many are Soldiers, that are no Captaines; so manie are Captaines that are no Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Right Sir: and as manie are Cittizens that are no Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: So, many are Cuckolds, that are no Citizens.
What ayle you Sir, with your robustious lookes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I would be glad to see for my money, I haue payde for my standing.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You are the Nobler Captaine Sir:
For I know manie that vsurpe that name,
Whose standings pay for them.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You are a Pedler.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: You are a Pot-gun.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Merchant, I would thou hadst an Iron Tale Like me.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fie Captaine, you are too blame.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Nay, Gods will, you are too blame indeede, if my Lord say so.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My lord's an Asse, and you are another.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Sweete Mistris Luce; let you and I withdraw, this is his humor.
Send for the Constable.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sirra, Ile beate you with a pudding on the change.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Thou dar'st as wel kisse the wide mouthed Canon
At his discharging, or performe as much
As thou dar'st speake: For Souldier you shall know,
Some can vse swords, that weare em not for show.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Why Captaine, though ye be a man of warre, you cannot subdue affection; you haue no alacritie in your eie, and you speake as if you were in a Dreame, you are of so melancholy and dull a disposition, that on my Conscience you would neuer get Children; Nay nor on my bodie neither: and what a sinne were it in me, and a most pregnant signe of Concupiscence, to marrie a man that wantes the mettall of Generation; since that is the blessing ordain'de for Marriage, procreation the onely end of it. Besides, if I could loue you; I shall be heer at home, and you in Cleeueland abroad; I among the bold Brittaines, and you among the hot shots.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: No more puffing good Captaine; leaue batteries with your breath, the short is this:
This worthy Count, this Morning makes my Son;
And with that happie Marriage this proceeds:
Worldly's my Name, Wordly must be my deeds.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will pray for Ciuill wars, to cut thy throat without danger Marchant,
I will turne Pyrate, but Ile be reueng'd on thee.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Do Captaine do, a halter will take vp our quarrel then.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Zoones, I will be reueng'd vpon ye all.
The strange aduenture th'art now to make
In that small Pinnace, is more perillous
Then any hazard thou could'st vndergo,
Remember a scorn'd Souldier tolde thee so.

div.stage: Exit Captaine.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Go walke the Captaine good sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p:
Good faith Sir, I had rather walke your horse, I will not meddle with him, I would not keepe him Companie
in his drinke for a world.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: But what good doo you Sir Abraham on my daughter,
I could be c'ne content, my Lucida
Would skip your wit, and looke vpon your wealth,
And this one day let Hymen Crowne ye all.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Oh no, she laughes at me; and scornes my sute
For she is wilder, and more hard withall,
Then Beast, or Bird, or Tree, or stonie wall.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Ha, Godamercie old Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yet might she loue me for my louely eies:

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I but perhaps your nose she doth despise.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yet might she loue me for my dimpled chin:

sp.speaker: Pend:
sp.p: I but she sees your Beard is verie thin.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yet might she loue me for my proper bodie:

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I, but she thinkes you are an arrant Noddie.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yet might she loue me, cause I am an heire:

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: I, but perhaps she does not like your ware.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yet might she loue me in despight of all:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I, but indeed I cannot loue at all.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Well Luce, respect Sir Abraham I charge you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Father, my vow is past: whilst the Earle liues
I neare will Marrie, nor will pine for him:
It is not him I loue now, but my humor.
But since my Sister he hath made his choise,
This wreath of Willow that begirts my browes,
Shall neuer leaue to be my Ornament
Till he be dead, or I be married to him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Life my Lord, you had best marrie em all three, Theyle neuer be content else.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I thinke so to.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: These are impossibilities; Come, Sit Abram. A little time will weare out this rash vow.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Shall I but hope?

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.p: Oh, by no meanes. I cannot endure these round Breeches, I am readie to sound at em.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: The Hose are comely.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: And then his left Leg: I neuer see it, but I thinke on a Plum-tree.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Indeed there's reason there should be some difference in my Legges, for one cost me twentie pound more then the other.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Introth both are not worth halfe the mony.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I hold my life one of them was broake, and cost so much the healing.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Right hath your Lordship said, twas broke indeed, At footeball in the Vniuersitie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I know he is in loue, by his Verse vaine.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: He cannot hold out on't: you shall heare.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Well since I am disdain'd; off Garters blew;
Which signifies Sir Abrams loue was true.
Off Cypresse blacke, for thou befits not me;
Thou art not Cypresse, of the Cypresse Tree,
Befitting Louers: Out greene Shoo-strings out,
Wither in pocket, since my Luce doth pout:
Gush eyes, thumpe hand, swell heart, Buttons flie open,
Thankes gentle Dublet; else my heart had broken.
Now to thy Fathers Countrey house at Babram,
Ride post; There pine and die, poore, poore Sir Abram.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Oh dolefull dumpe.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Nay you shall stay the wedding, Hark the Musick, Your Bride is readie.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Put Spirit in your Fingers; Lowder still,
And the vast Ayre with your enchantments fill. Exeunt Om.

div.head: Scen prima.
div.stage: Enter Neuill like a Parson.
div.l: THus for my friends sake haue I taken orders,
And with my reasons and some hyre besides:
Won the knowne Priest, that was to Celebrate
This Marriage, to let me assume his place:
And heere's the Charracter of his face and beard.
By this meanes, when my friend confronts the Maide,
At the Church doore (where I appointed him
To meete him, like my selfe: for this strange shape
He altogether is vnwitting of)
If she (as one Vice in that sex alone
Were a great Vertue) to inconstancy past,
Ioyne impudency, and sleight him to his face,
Shewing a resolution to this match.
By this attempt it will be frustrate;
And so we haue more time though but till night,
To worke to speake with her, or vse violence,
(For both my bloud and meanes are at his seruice.)
The reason too, I do this past his knowledge,
Is that his ioy may be the more compleat;
When being resolu'd shee's married and gone,
I can resolue him otherwise: Thus I know,
Good deeds shew double, that are timely done,
And ioy that comes past expectation.
div.stage: Enter Scudmore in Tawny.
div.l: Yonder he comes, dead in his melancholy:
Ile question him, and see if I can raise
His Spirit from that, it restlesse rests vpon:
He cannot know me. Ho, Good-morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Good-morrow to no liuing thing but one,
And that is Neuill: Oh, the Vowes, the Vowes,
The protestations and becomming Oaths
Which she has vtter'd to me, so sweet, so many,
As if she had beene couetous, not to leaue
One word for other Louers, which I pittied.
She saide indeede I did deserue em all;
Her lips made swearings sound of piety.
So sweet and prettily they came from her:
And yet this Morne shee's married to a Lord.
Lord, Lord, how often has she kist this hand,
Lost her selfe in my eyes, plaid with my haue,
And made me (a sinne I am not, subiect too)
Go away prou'd, emproued by her fauors,
And yet this Morne shee's married to a Lord.
The Bels were ringing as I came along.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tis for the great Marriage twixt

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Pray hold there, I know it too well.
The Tokens and the Letters I haue still:
The dangers I haue past for her deere sake,
By day and night to satisfie her wishes;
That Letter I so lately did receiue,
And yet this Morne shee's married to a Lord:
Oh memory, thou blessing to all men,
Thou art my curse and cause of misery,
That tel'st me what I haue bin in her eyes,
and what I am: as it is impossible
To find one good in the whole word of women:
But how I loose my selfe, and the remembrance
Of my deere friend, who said he would meet me heere.
What is this Priest that walkes before the Church?
Why walke you heere so earely, Sir?

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: I am appointed,
Heere to attend the comming of the Brides,
Old Sir Iohn Worldyes Daughters.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Are there two?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the eldest marries Count Frederick.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: The middlemost weares willow for his sake,
The youngest marries the rich Merchant Strange.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: He is right worthy, and my well knowne friend.
But Parson, if you marry Bellafront,
The horror of thy Conscience shall exceed
A Murtherers; Thou shalt not walke alone,
Nor eate, nor sleepe, but a sad Louers grones
and cursses, shall appeare and fright thy soule:
I tell thee Priest, they're sights, more terrible
Then Ghosts or Sprights, of which old wiues tell Tales,
Thou shalt run mad, thou shalt be damn'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Now God foresend, the reason Sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: She is contracted Sir, nay married
Vnto another man, though it want forme:
And such strange passages and mutuall Vowes,
T'would make your short haire start through your blacke
Cap, should you but heare it.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Sir, Ile take no notice
Of things, I do not know the iniur'd Gentleman,
May bring em after into the Spirituall Court,
and haue a faire pull on't, a poore Gentleman,
(For so I take him by his being deceiu'd)
Gainst a great Count, and an old wealthy Knight.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Thou Pancridge Parson; Oh, for my frend Nevil,
Some wile or other might remoue this Priest,
and giue vp breathing to crosse their intent.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Alas my deere friend.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Sir, do but you refuse To ioyne em.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Vpon what acquaintance Sir?
They are great persons, and I meane to rise,
I hope in time to haue three liuings man,
and this were not the way I take it Sir.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Why looke thee, there is Gold.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Oh by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: I seldome knew't refusd, yet by thy Coate;
But where it would haue bin a cause of good.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: But looke ye, you shall see I'me a Deuine,
Of Conscience quite opposite to a Lawyer,
Ile giue you Counsell Sir without a fee:
This way they are to come, if you dare doo't,
Challenge her as your owne, at the Church doore,
I will not hinder you. Musicke playes.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Oh harke they come,
Neuill my friend, well I must something do:
Oh, why should Musicke, which ioyes euerie part,
Strike such sharpe killing discords to my hart?

div.stage:
Musicke. Enter Sir Iohn Worldly, who meets the Parson, & entertaines him. Count, Bellafront, Strange, Kath. Lucida, with Willow. Pendant, Sir Inno: Ninnie, my Ladie Ninnie, Mrs. Wagtayle, S. Abram Melancholy. W.P. walk gravely
afore all softly on. Scudmore stands before, and a Boy singes to the tun'd Musicke.

div.head: The Song.
div.l: THey that for Worldly wealth do wed,
That buy and sell the Marriage bed:
That come not warm'd with the true fire,
Resolu'd to keepe this Vow entire.
To soone finde discontent,
To soone shall they repent.
But Hymen these are no such Louers,
Which thy burning Torch discouers:
Though they liue then many a yeare,
Let each day as new appeare
As this first; and delights
Make of all Bridall Nights:
Io: Hymen giue Consent,
Blessed are the Marriages that nere repent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now, who's this?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Young Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Tis young Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Canst thou this holy Church enter a Bride,
And not a Coarse meeting these eyes of mine.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Yes, by my troth, what are your eies to me,
But gray ones, as they are to euerie body,
The Gentleman I do a little know:
Hee's franticke sure, forward a Gods name there.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sister, this is not well, and will be worse.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh hold thy Thunder fast.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Ile aske my Lord: What is the matter Sir.

sp.speaker: World
sp.l: Some ydle words my Lord, t'may be haue past
Twixt Scudmore, and my Daughter heeretofore,
And he has dreamt em things of consequence.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Pish, nothing else; set forward.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: By your leaue.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Can there be such a soule in such a shape.
My Loue is subiect of such miserie,
Such strange impossibilities and mis-fortune,
That men will laugh at me, when I relate
The Storie of it, and conceiue I lye.
Why Madam that shall be, Lady in Posse, do Titles,
Honors, and Fortunes, make you so forgetfull?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You are insolent, nay strangely sawcie Sir,
To wrong me in this publicke fashion.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Sirrha, go too, there's Law.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: There is indeede,
And Conscience too, old Worldly thou hast one;
But for the other, wilde Virginia,
Blacke Affricke, or the shaggy Scithia,
Must send it ouer as a Merchandize,
Ere thou shew any heere.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord,
Say but the word, Ile force him from the doors.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I say the word, do it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: You my Lords fine foole?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I he Sir.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: No, nor you my Lord fooles foole.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Ware Boy, come backe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come back I say Sir Abraham. Intrant Templum

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Tis such a forward child.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: My passion and my cause of griefe's so great,
That it hath drownd all worthy parts in me:
As drinke makes Vertues vselesse in a man,
And with too much, kils naturall heat in him,
Or else I could not stand thus coldly tame,
and see them enter; but with my drawne sword
Should haile her by the haire vnto the Altar,
and Sacrifice her heart to wronged loue.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: On my life tis so.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Worthy friend, I am exceeding sorrie to see this,
But cannot helpe it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Ile follow, and vnfold all in the Church:
Alas, to what end, since her minde is chang'd,
Had she bin loyall, all the earthly Lords
Could not haue borne her; so, what hainous sinne
Hath she committed, God should leaue her then:
I neuer dreamt of lying with my Mother,
Nor wisht my Fathers death, nor hated Brothers;
Nor did betray Trust, nor lou'd money better
Then an accepted friend; No such base thought,
Nor act vnnaturall, possest this breast:
Why am I thus rewarded women, women?
Hee's mad by Heauen, that thinkes you any thing
But sensuall Monsters, and is neuer wife
Nor good, but when he hates you, as I now,
Ile not come neere one, none of your base sex
Shall know me from this time, for all your Vertues
are like the Buzzes, growing in the fields,
So Weakely fastned te'e, by Natures hand,
That thus much winde blowes all away at once,
Ye fillers of the world with Bastardy,
Worse then Diseases you are subiect too,
Know I do hate you all, will write against you,
and fight against you; I will eate no meate
Drest by a woman old or young, nor sleepe
Vpon a bed, made by their still giuen hands;
Yet once more must I see this Foeminine Diuell,
When I will looke her dead, speake her to hell;
Ile watch my time, this day to doo't, and then
Ile be in loue with death, and readier still Cornets.
His mortall stroke to take, then he to kill. Exit Scud.

div.stage: Loud Musieke. Enter as from the Church, Worldly, Neuill like the Parson, Count, Bellafront, Strange, Katherine, Sir Inno: Ninnie, Lady Ninnie, Sir Abra: Lucida, Wagtaile, Pendant, Poutes meetes em.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sweet is the loue purchast with difficulty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then this Crosse accident doth rellish ours.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I rather thinke ours happier my faire Kate,
Where all is smooth, and no rub checkes our course.

div.stage: Ent. Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Are ye married?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: The Deuill dance at your wedding: but for you I haue something else to say, let me see, heere are reasonable store of people, know all my beloued Brethren, (I speak it in the face of the Congregation) this woman I haue lyen with oftener.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: La: Nin.
sp.p: Before God, you are a wicked fellow to speak on't in this manner, if you haue.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Lyen with her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes, Good-morrow, God giue ye ioy. Exit.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: I am speechlesse with my anger, follow him,
If it be true, let her be prou'd a Whore;
If false, he shall abide the slander deerely.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Follow that list, I will not meddle with him.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Why speak'st thou not, to reconcile those looks
That fight sterne battels in thy husbands face.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Thou art not so vnworthy to beleeue him,
If I did thinke thou didst, I would not open
My lips, to satisfie so base a thought,
Sprung from the slander of so base a Slaue.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: It cannot be, Ile tell you by to morrow;
I am no Foole Kate. I will finde some time
To talke with this same Captaine, Pouts de'e call him,
Ile lye we'e to night.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Sir you shall not:
What staine my Honor hath receiu'd by this
Base Villaine, all the world takes notice of,
Marke what I Vow, and if I keepe it not,
May I be so giuen o're, to let this Rogue
Performe his slander; Thou that wert ordain'd,
And in thy Cradle markt to call me wife,
And in that Title made as my defence,
Yet suffered'st him to go away with life,
Wounding my Honor dead before thy face.
Redeeme it on his head, and his owne way,
Euen by the sword his long profession,
And bring it on thy necke out of the field:
and set it cleere amidst the tongues of men,
That all eyes may discerne it slandered,
Or thou shalt neare enjoy me as a wife:
By this bright Sun thou shalt not; Nay Ile thinke
As abiectly of thee, as any Mongrill
Bred in the Citty; Such a Cittizen
as the Playes flout still, and is made the subject
Of all the stages. Be this true or no,
Tis thy best course to fight.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Why Kate I say.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Pray pardon me, none feeles the smart but I,
Tis thy best course to fight, if thou be'st still,
and like an honest Tradesman eat'st this wrong:
Oh, may thy Spirit and thy state so fall,
Thy first borne childe may come to the Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Heauen I desire thee heare her last request,
and graunt it to, if I do slacke the first;
By thy assured Innocencie I sweare,
Thou hast lost me halfe the Honor I shall win,
In speaking my intent, Come lets to dinner.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: I must not eate nor sleepe, weepe till't be done.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sister, this resolution is not good,
Ill thriues that Marriage that begins in blood.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Sister, informe your selfe, I haue no Ladyship
To guild my infamie, or keepe tongues in awe:
If God loue Innocencie, I am sure he shall not
Loose in this action.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Nor ist the others life,
Can giue her to the world my perfect wife,
But what I do conceiue. It is not blood then
Which she requires, but her good name againe,
and I will purchase it; for by heauen thou art
The excellent'st new fashion'd Maide in this,
That euer eare shall heare a Tale told off.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: But heare ye.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Good, saue your labors, for by Heauen Ile doo't
If I doo't not, I shall be pointed at,
Proclaimd the Grand Rich Cuckold of the Towne;
Nay Wittall, euen by them are knowne for both.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Take your reuenge by Law.

sp.speaker: Stean.
sp.l: It will be thought
Your greatnesse, and our money carries it:
Forsome say some men on the backe of Law,
May ride and rule it like a patient Asse,
And with a Golden Bridle in the mouth,
Direct it vnto any thing they please,
Others report, it is a Spiders web
Made to intangle the poore helplesse Flies,
Whilst the great Spiders that did make it first,
and rule it, sit i'th midst secure and laugh,
My Law in this shall onely be my sword,
But peraduenture not this month or two.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: This month or two.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ile be your second then.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: You proffer too much honor, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And I will be your third.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Ile not be fourth, nor fift,
For the old Prouerbe's good, which long hath bin,
Sayes safest tis sleeping in a whole skin.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Godamercy Nab, Ile ha thee, and bee but for thy manhood.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Wife, my Ladie Ninnie, do ye heare your Son, he
speakes seldome, but when he speakes.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: He speakes Prouerbes Efaith.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, tis a pestlence Knight Mistris Lucida.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I and a pocky.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: This month or two, de'e loue me, not before,
It may be I will liue so long Fames Whore. Exit Kath.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: What lowring Starre rul'd my Natiuity,
Youle come to dinner?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Good-morrow brother,
Come, let's be merry in despight of all,
And make this day (as t'should be) festiuall.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: This sowre thwart beginning may portend
Good, and be crown'd with a delicious end.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Strange.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: So, Ile not see you till my taske be done,
So much false time I set to my intent,
Which instantly I meane to execute,
To cut off all meanes of preuention,
Which if they knew my day, they would assay:
Now for the Merchants honor, hit all right,
Kate, your yong Strange wil lie with you to night. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Wagtaile, the Page stealing after her, conceales himselfe.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What a stir is heere made about lying with a Gentlewoman, I haue beene lien with, a hundered and hundred times, and nothing has come on't, but haulke, hum, haulke, hum, oh, oh. Thus haue I done for this month or two, haulke, hum.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Ah Gods will, are you at it, you haue acted your Name too much, sweete Mistris is Wagtaile, this was wittily, though somewhat knauishly followed on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wag.
sp.p: Vmh, a my Conscience I am pepper'd, well thou tumblest not for nothing, for hee Daunces as well that got thee, and playes as well on the Violl, and yet hee must not Father thee, I haue better men; let mee remember them, and heere in my Melancholy. choose out one Rich enough, to rewarde this my stale Virginitie, or fitte enough, to marrie my little Honestie; Haulke, hauke.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Shee has a shrowde reach, I see that, what a casting shee keepes, marrie my Comfort is, wee shall heare by and by, who has giuen her the Casting Bottle.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Hawk, hawke, hawke, bitter, bitter, pray God I hurt not the Babe: Well, let mee see, Ile beginne with Knightes, Inprimis, Sir Iohn Doot-well, and Sir William Burnit.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: A hot Knight by my Faith, Dootwell and Burnit too.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: For old Sir Innocent Ninnie, my Maister, if I speak my Conscience looke yee, I cannot directly accuse him, much has hee been about, but done nothing; marrie for S. Abraham, I will not altogether quit him, let me see, theres foure Knights, now for Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And so shee'le come downe to the footmen.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Maister Louall, Maister Liueby't, and M. Pendant, huke, hi, vp, hi, vp.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: By this light I haue heard enough, shall I holde your belly too, faire Maide of the fashion?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What say ye Iacke Sawce?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Oh fie, ill Mutton, you are too angry; why look ye, I am my Lordes Page, and you are my Ladies Gentlewoman, wee should agree better, and I pray whether are you riding with this burthen in your Dosser.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why Sir, out of Towne, I hope tis not the firste time you haue seene a child carried out of Town in a Dosser, for feare of the Plague.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: You haue answer'd mee I promise you, but who put it in I pray.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not you Sir, I know by your asking.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I, alas, I know that by my Talent; for I remember thus much Philosophie of my Schoole-Maisters, Ex nihilo nihil fit; but come, setting this Duello of wit aside, I haue ouer-hearde your Confession, and your casting about for a Father, and in troth in meere Charitie, came in to relieue you. In the scrowle of Beasts, Horses, and Asses, that haue fedde vpon this Common of yours, you named one Pendant, Faith Wench let him bee the Father, hee is a verie handsome Gentleman I can tell you, in my Lordes
favour, Ile be both secret and your friend, to my Lord, let it be him, he shall either reward thee bountifully, or marrie thee.

sp.speaker: Wag..
sp.p: Sir you speak like an vnderstanding young Gentleman, and I acknowledge my selfe much bounde to you for your Counsell.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Will, Will. Within.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: My Lord has sent him to call mee, now I holde a wager ont, if thou beest not a Foole, as most waighting weomen are, thou'lt vse him in his kind.

div.stage: Enter Pendant.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why Will I say, go, my Lord cals extreamely,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Did not I say so, Come this is but a trick to send me off Sir. Exit Page.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.l: A notable little Rascall,
Prettis Mistris Wagtayle: why de'e walke so melancholy,
I sent him hence a purpose; Come shals do?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Do, what would you do, haue done too much alreadie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I am with childe by you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: By me? why by me? a good iest ifaith.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Youle finde it Sir in earnest.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Why, do you thinke I am such an Asse to beleeue nobody has medled with you, but I.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Do you wrong me so much to thinke otherwise.
This tis for a poore Damsell like my selfe,
To yeeld her Honour and her youth to any,
Who straite conceaues she does so vnto many,
and as I haue a soule to saue, tis true.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
Pray do not sweare, I do not vrge you too't; Zoones, now I am vndone; you walke somewhat rounde, Sweet-hart, has Nobody bin tampering with you els, think ont, for by this light, I am not worth the estate of an Apple wife, I do liue vpon commending my Lord, the Lorde of hoasts knowes it; and all the world besides, for mee to marrie thee, will vndo thee more,
and that thou maist keepe me, keepe thee in fashion,
sp.l: Sell thee to English, French, to Scot, and all,
Till I haue brought thee to an Hospitall:
and there I leaue you, ha you not heard nor read,
Of some base slaue, that wagging his faire head,
Does whistling at one end of his shop walke,
Whilst some Gay-man doth vomit bawdy talke
sp.p: In his wiues eares at the other; such a Rogue or woorse shall I be: For looke ye Mistris Wagtaile, I doo liue like a Chamelion vpon the ayre, and not like a Moale vppon the earth, Land I haue none, I pray God send me a graue when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Its all one, Ile haue you for your qualities.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: For my good ones, they are altogether vnknown, because they haue not yet bin seene, nor euer will bee, for they haue no being, in plaine tearmes, as God helpe me, I haue none.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: How, came you by your good cloths.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: By vndoing Taylors, and then my Lord (like a Snake) casts a sute euerie quarter, which I slip into; therfore, thou art worse then mad, if thou wilt cast away thy self vpon me

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why, what mends will you make me, can you giue me some sum of money to marrie me to some Tradesman, as the play saies.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No by my troth: but tell mee this, has not Sir Abraham bin familiar with you.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Faith, not enough to make vp a childe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Couldst bee content to marrie him.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I by my troth, and thanke ye too,

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Has he but kist thee?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes, and something more beside that.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Nay, and there ha beene any iot of the thing, beside that, Ile warrant thee lay the childe to him, stand stifly to it, leaue the rest to me, By that Foole thou shalt saue thy honestie. Exeunt

div.head: scen. Prima.
div.stage: Enter Strange, knocking at a doore. Enter a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I Yes Captaine Powts heere pray?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir he does.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I prethee tell him heere's a Gentleman Would speake with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What may I call your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: No matter for my name.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Troth Sir, the Captaine is somewhat doubtfull of strangers; and being as most Captaines are, a little in debt, I know he will not speake with you, vnlesse you send your Name.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Tell him my name is Strange, that I am come
About that businesse he spake off to day. Exit Seruant.
To haue sent a formall Challenge by a Gentleman,
He being to choose his time, might peraduenture
Haue made him shift himselfe the sooner ouer.

div.stage: Enter Powts aboue.

sp.speaker: Powts.
sp.p: Sir, I know your businesse, you are come to serue a warrant, or a Scitation, I will not speake with you: and get you gone quickly too, or I may happen send a Bullet through your Mazard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Strange Crosse, past expectation: well Ile try,
My other course may speed more happily. Exit.

div.stage: Musicke.
Enter with Table Napkins. Count, Worldly, Neuill, Pendant, Sir Innocent, Lady, Sir Abraham, Seruants with wine, Plate, Tobacco and pipes.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Sir, had you borne vs company to Church,
You had beene the better welcome.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Faith you had, I must needs say so to.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And I must needs say as my Lord saies.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Sir Iohn I thanke you, and my honor'd Lord:
But I am sorrie for this other Newes
Concerning Mistris Kate, and my good friend.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Tis certaine true: He keepes his word well too,
He saide he would come to dinner.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: All we cannot get M. Katherine out of hir chamber.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Oh good old woman, she is topshackeld.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Tis pestlence Sacke, and cruell Clarret. Knight, stand to me Knight I say, vp, a cold stomacke; giue me my Aqua-vitae bottle.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Oh Guiniuer, as I am a Iustice of peace and Coram, t'were a good deed to commit thee, Fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Sir Abra.
sp.p: Why alas, I cannot helpe this and I should bee hang'd, shee'le bee as drunke as a Porter: Ile tell you my Lorde, I haue seene her so bepisse the Rushes, as shee has danc'd at a Wedding: Her bellie, and that Aqua-vitae bottle, haue almost vndone my Father: Well I thinke in Conscience, shee is not my naturall begotten Mother.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Well said my wise Sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh this Musicke and good Wine is the soule of all the world.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Come, wil your Lordship make one at Primero, vntill your Bride come foorth.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: You can play well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Whol?

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Who my Lord, the onelie player at Primero i'th Court.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I'de rather play at Bowles.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My Lords for you for that too: the onely, Bowler in London, that is not a Church warden.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Can he fence well too M. Pendant?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Who my Lord? the only Fencer in Christendom, hee'l hit you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: He shall not hit me, I assure you now.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Is he good at the exercise of drinking Sir?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Who my Lord; the onely Drunkard i'th Woild, drinker I would say.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Godamercie for that.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: I would he heard him.

sp.speaker: Neu,
sp.p: Oh fie no, none so good as my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: Hardly, berladie, hardlie.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now, whos's this?

div.stage: Enter Scudmore like a Seruingman, with a Letter.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: What would you?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: I would speake with the Ladie Bellafront,
From the young Ladie Lucie.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: You had best send in your Letter, shee is withdrawne.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: My Ladie gaue me charge of the deliuery,
And I must doo't my selfe, or carrie it backe.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: A trustie seruant, that way leads you to her.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This trust in Seruants is a Iewell; Come,
Let vs to Bowles i'th Garden. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Blessed fate.

div.stage: Scudmore passeth one doore, and entereth the other, where Bellafront sits in a Chaire, vnder a Taffata Canopie,

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Oh thou, whose words and actions seemd to me,
As innocent as this smooth sleepe, which hath
Lockt vp thy powers: would thou hadst slept, when first
Thou sent'st and proferredst me beautie and loue:
I had bin ignorant then of such a losse,
Happie's that wretch in my opinion,
That neuer ownd scarse Iewels, or bright Somes,
He can loose nothing but his constant wants:
But speaklesse is his plague, that once had store,
and from superfluous state fals to be poore:
Such is my hell-bred hap, could Nature make
So faire a superficies, to enclose
So false a heart; This is like gilded Tombes,
Compacted of Iet Pillars, Marble stones,
Which hide from's stinking Flesh, and rotten bones.
Pallas so sat (methinkes) in Hectors Tent;
But time so precious and so dangerous
Why do I loose thee? Madam, my Lady, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Beleeue me my deare friend, I was enforcst: Ha,
I had a Dreame as strange as thou art fellow,
How cam'st thou hether? What's thy businesse?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: That Letter Madam tels you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Letter: Ha?
What doost thou mocke me? Heere is nothing writ.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Can you read any thing then in this face?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh Basiliske, remooue thee from my sight,
Or thy harts bloud shall pay thy rash attempt.
Ho, Who attends vs there?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Stirre not a foote,
And stop your clamorous acclamations,
Or by the bitternesse of my fresh wrongs,
Ile send your Ladiship to the Deuill quicke;
I know the hazard I do vndergo,
and whatsoere after becomes of me,
Ile make you sure first: I am come to speake,
and speake I will freely, and to bring backe
Your Letters, and such things you sent; and then,
Ile nere see those deceiuing eyes agen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh, I am sicke of my corruption,
For Godsake do not speake a word more to me.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Not speake, yes woman, I will rore a lowd,
Call thee the falsest faire that euer breath'd,
Tell thee, that in this marriage, thou hast drown'd
All vertue, left to credit thy weake sex,
which being (as t'were) committed to thy trust,
Thou traiterously hast betraid it thus.
Did I intice, or euer send thee guists
To allure thee, to reflect a beame on me?
Nay, didst not thou thy selfe send and inuent
Past humaine wit, our meanes of intercourse?
Why dost thou then proue base vnto thy selfe,
Periur'd and impious, know the good thou hast lost
In my opinion; doth outvalue farre
The airy honors thou art married to.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh peace, for you speake sharpnesse to my soule
More torturous, then hels plagues to the damn'd,
For loue sake heare me speake.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: For loues sake, no:
Loue is my surfet, and is turn'd in me
To a disease.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Tyrant, my knees shall beg,
Till they get liberty for my tongue to speake,
Drown'd almost in the Riuers of mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: What canst thou say, art thou not married?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Alas I was enforst, first by the threats
Of a seuere Father, that in his hand
Did gripe my fortunes; next to that, the fame
Of your neglect, and liberall tongue,
Which bred my honour an eternall wrong.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Pish, these are painted causes, till this Morne
He liu'd not in this land, that durst accuse
My intergritie, of such an ignorance.
But take your Letters heere, your paper Vowes,
Your Picture, and your Bracelets: and if euer
I build againe vpon a womans faith,
May sence forsake me: I will sooner trust
Dice, or a reconciled enemy: Oh God,
What an internall ioy my heart has felt,
Sitting at one of these same idle playes,
When I haue seene a Maids inconstancie
Presented to the life; how glad my eies
Haue stole about me, fearing least my lookes
Should tell the companie contented there,
I had a Mistris free of all such faults.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! still retaine her, deare Scudmore heare me.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Retaine thee so, it is impossible,
Art thou not married? Tis impossible,
Oh no! I do despise thee, and will flie
As far on earth as to the Antipodes,
and by some learn'd Magitian, whose deepe art
Can know thy residence on this Hemispheare;
There Ile be placst, my feete iust against thine,
To expresse the opposite Nature, which our harts
Must henceforth hold.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh rather shoot me friend,
Then let me heare thee speake such bitternesse.
Oh pitty me, redeeme from the hell
That in this Marriage I am like to feele,
Ile rather flye to barren wildernesses,
and suffer all wants with thee Scudmore, then
Liue with all plentie in this husbands armes,
Thou shalt perceiue I am not such a woman,
That is transported with vaine dignities,
Oh thy deare words haue knockt at my harts gates,
and entred: They haue pluckt the Diuels Vizard.
(That did deforme this face, and blinde my soule)
Off, and thy Bellafront presents her selfe,
(Lau'd in a Bath of contrite Virginall teares,)
Cloath'd in the Originall beautie that was thine:
Now for thy loue to God, count this not done,
Let time go backe, and be as when before it,
Or from thy memorie race it for euer.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, was there euer such strange creatures fram'd,
Why dost thou speake such foolish sencelesse things?
Can thy forsaking him redeeme thy fault?
No, I will neuer mend an ill with worse.
Why this example will make weomen false,
When they shall heare it, that before were true,
For after ill examples we do fly,
But must be vow'd to deeds of piety:
Oh woman, woman, woman, woman, woman,
The cause of future and Originall sinne,
How happy (had you not) should we haue beene,
False where you kisse, but murthering in your ire,
Loue all that woe, know all men you desire.
Vngratefull, yet most impudent craue,
Torturous as hell, insatiate as the graue:
Lustfull as Monkies, grinning in your ease,
Whom if we make not Idols, we neare please.
More vainly proud then fooles, as ignorant;
Baser then Parasites, Witches that enchant
And make vs sencelesse, to thinke death or life
Is yours to giue, when onely our beleefe
Doth make you able to deceiue vs so,
Begot by Drunkards, to breed sin and wo.
As many foule diseases hide your vaines,
as there are mischiefes coin'd in your quicke braines;
Not quicke in wit, fit to performe least good,
But to subuert whole States, shed Seas of blood;
Twice as deceitfull as are Crocodiles,
For you betray both waies; with teares and smiles,
Yet questionlesse there are as good, as bad:
Hence, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Heare me, and thou shalt go:
I do confesse I do deserue all this,
Haue wounded all the faith my sex doth owe,
But will recouer it, or pay my life:
Striue not to go, for you shall heare me first,
I charge thee Scudmore, thou hard-hearted man,
Vpon my knees: thou most implacable man,
since penitence
and satisfaction to, gets not thy pardon,
I charge thee vse some meanes to set me free,
Before the Reuels of this night haue end,
Preuent my entering to this marriage bed;
Or by the memorie of Lucretiaes knife,
Ere Morne Ile die a Virgin, though a wife. Exit.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Pish do, the world will haue one mischiefe lesse. Exit

div.stage: Enter Sir Abraham throwing downe his Bowles.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Bowle they that list, for I will Bowle no more,
Cupid that little Bowler in my brest
Rubs at my heart, and will not let me rest.
I, I, you may crie rub, flie to your Bowles,
For you are free, loue troubles not your iowles,
But from my head to heele; from heele to hart,
Behind, before, and round about I smart,
Then in this Arbor sitting all alone,
In dolefull Dittie, let me howle my mone.
Oh Boy, leaue pricking for I vaile my Bonnet,
Giue me but breath while I do write a Sonnet.

div.stage: Enter Pendant.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I haue lost my monie, and Sir Abraham too, yonder he sits at his Muse by heauen, drownd in the Ocean of his loue, Lord how hee labours, like a hard bounde Poet, whose braines had a frost in em, now it comes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I die, I sigh.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: What after you are dead? Verie good,

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I die, I sigh, thou precious stonie Iewell.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Good: because she is hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I die. Write.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: He has di'de three times, and come againe.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: I sigh thou precious stonie Iewell,
Wearing of silke, why art thou still so cruell. Write.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Oh Newington conceit, and quieting else.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Thy seruant Abraham sends this foolish Dittie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You say true in troth Sir.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Thy Seruant Abra. sends this foolish Dit Write
sp.l: Tie vnto thee, pittie both him and it. Write

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Tie vnto thee: well, if shee do not pittie both, tis pittie she should liue.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: But if thou still wilt poore Sir Abra: frump Write
Come grim death come, heere giue thy mortall thumpe.
So now Ile read it together.
I die, I sigh, thou precious stonie Iewell,
Oh wherefore wear'st thou Sulke, yet art so cruell:
To thee thy Ninnie sends this foolish Dit
Tie, and pittie both him and it,
If thou denie, and still Sir Abraham frumpe,
Come grim death come, heere giue thy mortall thumpe.
Let mee see, who shall I get now, to set too a dumpish Note.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: In good faith I doo not know, but Nobody that is wise, I am sure of that. It will be an excellent matter sung to the knacking of the tongues. But to my businesse, God saue the right Worthy and Woorshipfull Sir Abraham: what musing and writing: oh, this loue will vndoo vs all, and that made me preuent loue, and vndoo my selfe: but what newes of Mistris Lucida, ha, will shee not come off, not cannot you come on little Abraham.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Faith, I haue courted her, and courted her: and she does as euerie bodie else does, laughes at all I can doo or say.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Laughes, why that's a signe she is pleasd; doo you not know when a woman laughes, shees pleasd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I but she laughes most shamefully, & most scornfully.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Scornfully, hang her, shees but a bable.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Shees the fitter for my turne Sir, for they will not sticke to say, I am a foole for all I am a Knight.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Loue has made you witty little Nab, but what a mad villaine art thou, a striker, a fiftieth part of Hercules, to get one Wench with Childe, and go a wooing to another.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: With child, a good iest efaith, whom haue I got with child.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why Mistris Wagtaile is with childe, and will bee deposd as yours, she is my Kinswoman, and I wold be loth our house should suffer any disgrace in her, if there be law in England, which there should be, if wee may iudge by their Consciences, or if I haue any friendes, the Wench shall take no wrong, I cannot tell, I thinke my Lorde will sticke to me.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p:
De'e heare, talke not to me of Friends, Lawe, or Conscience, if your Kinswoman say she is with Childe by me, your Kinswoman is an arrant whore; Vds-will, haue
you no bodie to put your Guls vppon but Knights? That Wagtaile is a whore, and Ile stand to it.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Nay, you haue stood to it alreadie; but to call my Cozen whore, you haue not a mind to haue your throat cut: ha you?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Truth no great minde Sir.

div.stage: Drawes his sword.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Recant your words, or die.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Recant, oh base; out sword, my honor keepe,
Loue, thou hast made a Lyon of a Sheepe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But will you fight in this quarrell.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I am resolu'd.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Hart, I haue puld an olde house ouer my heade; heeres like to bee a tall fray, I perceiue a foole's valianter then a Knaue at all times, would I were well riddle of him, I had as liue meet Hector God knowes, if he dare fight at all: they are all one to mee, or to speake more modernly, with one of the Roaring Boyes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Haue you done your prayers?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Pray giue me leaue Sir, put vp an't please you: are you sure my Cossen Wagtaile is a Whore?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: With sword in hand I do it not recant.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Well, it shall neuer bee saide Iacke Pendant would venter his blood in a Whores quarrell: but Whore or no Whore, she is most desperately in Loue with you, praises your head, your face, your nose, your eies, your mouth; the fire of her commendations, makes the potte of your good parts runne ouer; and to conclude, if the whore haue you not, I thinke the Pond at Islington, will bee her Bathing-tubbe, and giue an ende to mortall Miserie, but if shee belye you (pray put vppe Sir:) she is an arrant whore, and so let her go.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Does she so loue me say you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes, yes, out of all question the whore does loue you abhominable.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: No more of these soule termes if she do loue me,
That goes by fate, I know it by my selfe,
Ile not denie but I haue dallied with her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I, but hang her who whoore dallying will get no Children.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Another whore, and draw; where is the Girle.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Condouling her misfortune in the Gallery,
Vpon the rushes, sitting all alone,
and for Sir Abrahams loue venting her mone.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: I know not what to say, Fates aboue all,
Come lets go ouer-heare her, be this true,
Welcome my Wagtayle, scornfull Luce adue. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: One way it takes yet, tis a Fooles condition,
Whom none can loue: out of his penurie,
To catch most greedily at any wench
That giues way to his loue, or faignes her owne,
First vnto him, and so Sir Abraham now
I hope will buy the poole where I will Fish,
Thus a quicke Knaue makes a fat foole his dish. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Powts.

sp.speaker: Powts.
sp.p: I haue plaide the melancholy Asse, and partlie the Knaue, in this last businesse, but as the Parson said that got the wench with child, Tis done now Sir, it cannot bee vndone, and my purse or I must smart for it.

div.stage: Enter Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your Trunks are shipt, and the Tide fals out about twelue to night.

sp.speaker: Powts.
sp.p: Ile away, this Law is like the Basiliske, to see it first, is the death ont this night: and noble London farewell, I will neuer see thee more, till I be knighted for my Vertues. Let me see, when shall I returne; and yet I doo not thinke but there are a great manie dubd for their Vertues; otherwise how could there be so many poor knights, what att thou? whats thy newes?

div.stage: Enter Strange like a Souldier amazedly.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Zoones, a man is faine to breake open doores, ere he can get in to you.
I would speake with a Generall sooner.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir you may, hee owes lesse peraduenture: or if more, he is more able to pay't: What ar't?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: A Soldier, one that liues vpon this Busse Ierkin, t'was made of Fortunatus his pouch; and these are the points I stand vpon, I am a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A counterset Rogue you are.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: As true a Rogue as thy selfe: Thou wrong'st me, send your man away, go too, I haue strange and welcome businesse to impart, the Merchant is deade, for shame let's walke into the fields, send away your man.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Heere is a Letter from the lusty Kate
That tels you all, I must not giue it you
But vpon some conditions. Let vs walke,
and send away your man.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Go Sirrha, and bespeake Supper at the Beare, and prouide Oares, Ile see Graues-end to night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman will run mad after you then, Ile tell you more, let's walke. Exit.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Scudmore and Neuill.
div.l: I See great'st Spirits can serue to their owne ends,
Were you the seeming Seruing-man that past by?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: By my sad heart I was, and not a Tittle
Of my relation to thee wrong or faign'd.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Introth you were too blame to venter so,
Mischiefes finde vs, we need not mischiefes seeke;
I am not ti'de to that opinion,
They are like women, which do alwaies shun
Their louers and pursuers, and do follow
With most ranke appetites them that do flye:
All mischiefe that I had is but one woman,
and that one woman all mischance to me,
Who speaks worst of them, then's the best of men,
They are like shaddowes, mischiefes are like them.
Death feares me, for in troth I seeke him out;
The Sun is stale to me, to morrow Morne
as this, t'will rise, I see no difference;
The night doth visit me, but in one roabe,
She brings as many thoughts as she weares Starres
When she is pleasant, but no rest at all,
For what new strange thing should I couet life then?
Is not she false, whom onely I thought true?
Shall time to shew his strength make Scudmore liue.
Till (perish the vicious thought) I loue not thee,
Or thou deere friend, remoue thy heart from me.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Time is as weake for that, as he is old,
Take comfort, and attend this counsell friend,
This match is neither Sacred nor sure,
Close Fate annihilates what Opinion makes,
and since she is resolu'd this night to die,
If you do not redeeme her, giue the meanes,
Or her bloud (credit me) will spring heauier greefes,
Sorer and stranger in thy oppressed hart
Then her false loue before. Besides, tis you
My Scudmore that are false, if you will not
Consent to let her make Vowes good, which were
But in a possibility to be broke,
This her Repentance casts her vice quite off:
and if you leaue her now, you take it on,
Nay you incurre a bloody mortall sinne,
You do become an actuall murtherer.
If you neglect her, she will kill her selfe
This night, by poyson, knife, or other meanes,
God giues you power to crosse her desperate will,
and if you saue not where you may, you kill.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Why can my Noble and wise friend, thinke still
That what a woman saies, her heart doth meane?
Can you beleeue that she wil kil hir selfe.
Tis a full houre since she spake the word,
and God forbid, that any womans minde
Should not be chang'd and chang'd in a long houre.
She is by this time in her Lordly armes,
and like pleas'd Iuno, claspt by Iupiter,
Forgets the plaints of poore mortality,
Such state, such pride, as Poets shew her in,
Incenst with Ioues loose scapes vpon the earth,
She cast on me at our encountering;
As cold and heauie, as a Rocke of Ice
In her loue to me, which while I there staide,
My bitter and hot words resolu'd a little,
(Iust as the Sun doth Ice) I soften'd her,
and made her drowne her fault in her owne teares,
But thinke you she holds this flexible vaine:
No, I me remou'd, and shee's congeal'd againe.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: How well does Scudmore speake, ill for himselfe,
Wit's a disease, that fit employment wants,
Therefore we see, those happiest in best parts,
and vnder-borne fortunes vnder their merrits,
Grow to a sullen enuie, hate, and scorne
Of their Superiors; and at last, like winds
Breake forth into rebellious ciuil warres,
Or priuate Treasons; none so apt for these,
as melancholy wits fetter'd with neede.
How free's the Rusticke Swaine from these assaults,
He neuer feeles a passion all his life,
But when he cannot sleepe, or hunger gripes;
And though he want Reason, Wit, Art, nay Sence,
Is not so sencelesse to capitulate,
and aske God why he made not him as great
As that same foolish Lord, or that rich knaue:
His braines with nothing does Negotiate,
But his hard Husbandry, which makes him liue.
But haue we worthy gifts, as Iudgement, Learning,
Ingenious sharpnesse, which wise God indeed,
Doth seldome giue out of his equall hand,
But ioyn'd with pouertie to make it euen
With Riches which he clogs with ignorance,
We vent our blessing in prophane conceits,
Or in strong Arguments against our selues,
Foule Bawdry, and starke blindly hold it best,
Rather to loose a soule, then loose a iest.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Ill tearmes my friend, this wit in any man,
(For that but season'd with discretion)
Holds him in awe of all these blemishes,
Free's him of enuie, doth Phylosophize
His Spirit, that he makes no difference
