Twixt man and man, twixt fortunes high and low,
But as the thicker they with vertues grow,
Freedome and bondage wit can make alone;
So t'would by being left, and being lou'd,
If I had any of it temper'd so:
But you haue spoke all this condemning me,
For hauing wit to speake against my selfe,
But Ile be rul'd by you in all.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Then thus:
To night by promise, I do giue a Maske,
as to congratulate the Bridall day,
In which the Count, Pendant, and the wise Knight,
Will be most worthy dancers, Sir you shall,
Learne but my part, which I will teach you to,
as nimbly as the Vsher did teach me,
and follow my further directions,
Though I i'th Morne were a prodigious wight,
Ile giue thee Bellafront in thine armes to night.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: I am your property, my Enginer
Prosper your purposes, shine thou eie of heauen,
and make thie lowring Morne, a smiling Eeuen. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Cap. Powts with a Letter, and Strange like a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Oh, these are Lambeth fields.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Strange murther'd on the wedding day by you,
At his owne Brides appointment, for my sake?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: As dead as Charity.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: This sounds not well.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Zoones, you may say as well I am the man,
as doubt he liues, a plague of your beleefe,
De'e know this bloodie Ruffe which she has sent,
Least you should be incredulous, and this Ring
Which you haue seene her weare?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I know the Ring,
and I haue seene the Ruffe about his necke,
This comes of enforc'd marriages; Where was't done?
And how escap't you?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Sir receiue it briefly:
I am her Kinsman, and being newly come
Ouer, and not intending to stay long,
Tooke this day to go see my Cozen Worldly,
(For so my Name is) where I found all of them
So deepely drenched in the Bridall cup,
That sleepe had tane possession of their eies;
Bacchus had giuen them such an ouerthrow,
Their bodies lay like slaughtered carkasses;
One heere, one there, making such anticke faces,
as drunkennesse had mockt at drunkennesse,
Introth their postures and their sleepe like death,
(For their's, was liker death, then sober sleepe)
Remembred me of body-scattered fields,
after the bloudie battels I haue seene,
Twas such a season. To make short my tale,
as Fate had said, Now murthers may be done
and ne're reueal'd, approaching further, I
Lighted vpon a Chamber, where your Loue
Sat by this Merchant cast drunke on the bed,
Shee weeping and lamenting her mishap,
assur'd both of my daring, and my trust,
Fell flat vpon the ground, then rais'd her selfe,
Hung on my necke, then sunke downe to my legs,
Told all things past to day, and neuer ceast
Till I had tane life from that halfe dead man
Before, whom straight I strangled with this Rope.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You haue shew'd some kindnes to mee, I must loue you Sir,
What did you with his bodie?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Hauing first
By her direction put on these his Cloaths,
That like the Murther'd man, the safelyer
I might passe with her, being her Husbands shape,
If any of the Seruants had beene wak'd,
She shew'd me to a necessarie vault,
Within a Closset in the Chamber too,
and there I threw the bodie.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Whence this bloud?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That she her selfe first, let out of his vaines,
Wherein she dipt the Ruffe about his necke:
and said, Go beare this Ensigne of my loue,
To assure him what I dar'd for his deare sake.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Where is the Maide?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Captaine a Maide for you,
But well you know (I hope) she is no Maide,
But Maide or no Maide, she is at my Mothers,
Whence I will bring her whether you'le appoint
To night, and let this Tide conuey all hence,
For staying will be something perillous.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir, I wil kill two men for you till then
I owe my life to you, and if euer Rackes,
Strapadoes, wheele, or any torturous Engine,
Euen from the Roman Yoke, to the Scotch Boote,
Force me discouer you, or her, to Law,
Pray God the Merchant may re-spire againe,
But what a Villaine haue I beene to wrong her?
Did she not tell you how I iniur'd her?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: She said you challeng'd her, and publickly
Told you had lay'n with her, but Truths no wrong.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Truth, t'was more false then Hell, & you shall see me,
(As Well, as I can repent of any sinne)
Aske her forgiuenesse for wounding of her Name,
and gainst the world recouer her lost fame.
Kind soule, would I could weepe, to make amends
Why I did slander her at the Church doore.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: The more base Villaine thou. Strike him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Thou vnspeakeable Rascall, thou a Souldier,
a Captaine of the Suburbs, a poore forst,
That with thy Slops, and Cat a Mountaines face,
Thy blather chops, and thy robustious words,
Fright'st the poore whore, and terribly dost exact,
a weekely Subsidie, twelue pence a peece,
Whereon thou liu'st, and on my Conscience
Thou snapst besides, with cheats and Cut-purses.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hart, this is some rayling Poet, why you Rogue?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Thou Rogue, far worse then Rogues, thou slanderer

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Thou worse then slanderous Rogues, thou murderer

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Tis well remember'd, I will cut thy throat,
To appease that Merchants soule, which ne're will rest,
Till some reuenge be taken on thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ile kill the first, and in thy vitall floud, Fight.
Wash my hands cleane of that yong Merchants bloud.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You fight as if you had fought afore,
I can still hold my sword, come on Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Zoones can you ward so well, I thinke you are one of the Noble science of Defence.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: True, a'th Science of Noble Defence I am,
That fight in safegard of a vertuous name. Cadit Cap:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh, now I vnderstand you, and you stand ouer me, My hurts are not mortal, but you haue the better, if your name be Wordly, be thankefull for your fortune.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Giue me thy sword, or I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Some wiser then some, I loue my reputation wel, yet I am not so valiant an asse, but I loue my life better, thers my

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Then get vpon my back, come al shalbe wel.
Ile carry thee vnto a Surgeon first, & then vnto thy wench, sword
Come we are friends.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Godamercy, zoones methinkes I see my selfe in
Moore-fields, vpon a wodden leg, begging three pence.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I thanke thee heauen for my successe in this,
To what perfection is my busines growne. Exit with Cap. on his backe.
Seldom or neuer is right ouerthrowne.

div.stage: Enter Pendant, and Mistris Wagtaile, with worke sowing a purse.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: They say euerie woman has a Sprindge to catch a Wood-cocke, remember my instructions, and let mee see what a Paradice thou canst bring this foole into. 15. hundered a yeare wench, wil make vs all merrie, but a foole to boot; why we shall throw the house out at window; Let mee see, there are two thinges in this foolish Transitorie world, which should be altogether regarded, profite and pleasure, or pleasure and profit, I know not which to place first, for indeed, they are Twinnes, and were borne together; for Profit, this Marriage (God speed it) marries you to it, and for pleasure, if I helpe you not to that as cheape as any man in England, call me Cut, and so remember my instructions, for Ile go fetch Sir Abraham. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Your instructions; Nay faith, you shall see I haue as fruitfull a braine as a belly, you shall heare some additions of my owne, my fantasie euen kickes like my Bastard: well Boy, for I know thou art Masculine, neither thy Father nor thy Mother had any foeminine qualitie, but one, and that was to take a good thing when it was proffer'd; when thou inherit'st Land, strange both to thy Father and Grandfather, and rid'st in a Caroch, it may bee thy Father an old Footeman, will be running by thy side, but yonder comes the Gentle Knight, and my Squire.

div.stage: Enter Sir Abraham and Pendant stealing.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Vnfortunate Damsel, why doost thou loue
Where thou hast sworn it neuer to reueale?
May be he would vouchsafe to looke on thee
Because he is a Knight, is it thy terror,
Why peraduenture he is Knight-hoods Mirror.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: De'e heare Sir Abraham?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Yes, with standing teares.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Beauis on Arundell with Morglay in hand,
Neere to my Knight in prowesse doth not stand;
They say Sir Beauis flew both Bore and Draggon,
My Knight for that can drinke vp a whole Flaggon,
a thing as famous now amongst our men,
as killing Monsters were accounted then,
Tis not thy legge, no, were it twice as good,
Throwes me into this melancholy mood,
Yet let me say and sweare, in a crosse Garter,
Poles neuer shew'd to eies a louelier quarter.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I, but all this while she does not name mee, shee may meane Somebody else.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Meane Somebodie else, you shall heare her name you by and by.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Courteous Sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Law ye there.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Oh, thy verie name,
Like to a Hatchet cleaues my heart in twaine,
When first I saw thee in those little Breeches,
I laugh'd for ioy, but when I heard thy speeches
I smil'd downe right, for I was almost franticke,
A moderne Knight should be so like an Anticke,
In words and deeds, those Pinkanies of thine,
For I shall ne're be blest to call them mine.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Say not so, Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: How they did run not rheumatickly run,
But round about the roome, one ouer one,
That wide mouth no, small, no, but Middle-size,
That Nose Dominicall, that head, like wise.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Very good, de'e marke that head like wise?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: She has an excellent wit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Ile now into her, Sir obserue what followes, Now Turtle mourning still For the partie, for whome are you working that purse?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: For me I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What newes good Cozen, I hope you haue not reueal'd my Loue.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Yes faith, I haue acquainted the Knight withall, and thou maist be asham'd to abuse a Gentleman to slaunderously, he sweares he ne're lay with you.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Lay with mee, alas no, I say not so, nor no man liuing;
but there was one night aboue the rest, that I dreamt he lay with me, and did you ne're heare of a child begot in a Dreame.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: By this light, that very night I dreamt shee lay with me.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: I but Sir Abra: is no dreaming knight: in short, he contemnes you, he scornes you at his heeles.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: By God so he lyes, I haue the most adoo to forbeare, but that I would heare a little more.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: And has sent this halter, you may hang your selfe, or you may cut your throat, heere's a knife too.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Well, I will loue him in despight of all,
How ere he vses me, tis not the shame
Of being examin'd, or the feare of whipping.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Make as if thou would'st kill thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Should moue me, wold but he vouchsafe his loue,
Beare him this purse fil'd with my latest breath. Blowes in it
I lou'd thee Abraham Ninnie, euen in death. Offers to stab

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Hold, hold, thy Knight commands thee for to hold,
I sent no halter, poore soule how it pants,
Take Courage, looke vp.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Looke, Sir Abra: in person comes to see you.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Oh, let me die then in his worships armes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Liue long and happy to produce thy Baby,
I am thy Knight, and thou shalt be my Lady:
Frowne Dad, fret Mother, so my loue looke chearely,
Thou hast my heart, and thou hast bought it dearely,
And for your paines, if Abraham liue to inherit,
He will not be vnmindfull of your merit;
Weare thou this Ring, whilst I thy labors Taske,
This Purse weare in my Cap, anon i'th Maske.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Oh happie woman.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: To Supper let's, and merry be as may be.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Now God send euerie wise knight such a Lady. Exeunt

div.head: Scen. prima.
div.stage: Enter Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Titles and State de'e call it: Oh Content!
Thou art both beauty, meanes, and all in marriage:
Ioy dwels not in the Princes Pallaces,
They that enuie em do not know their cares,
Were I the Queene of Gold, it could not buy
An houres ease, for my oppressed heart.
Oh, were this Wedlocke knot to tie againe,
Not all the State and glorie it containes,
Ioyn'd with my Fathers fury, should enforce
My rash consent; but Scudmore thou shalt see,
This false heart (in my death) most true to thee.
sp.stage: Shewes a Knife hanging by her side.
sp.l: My Lord, my Father, all the Companie
Did note my sodaine sadnesse now at Supper,
Yet came I out, and put on faigned mirth,
And meane to sit out this nights Reuels too,
To auoide all suspect may grow in em,
Least my behauiour should my intent reueale:
Our greefes (like loue) we hardly can conceale,
Yon comes my Sisters: Are the Maskers ready?

div.stage: Enter Lucida with her Willow Garland on, and Katherine.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: They are gone to dresse themselues, M. Neuil's come
I would I had not vow'd to liue a Maide,
I am a little taken with that Gentleman,
And yet if Marriage be so full of ill,
Let me be married to my Gyrlond still.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Introth thy State is happier much then ours,
Were neuer two (like vs) vnfortunate.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Thy case indeed, I needs must pitty much,
Because I thinke thy Vertue slander'd,
But for my Ladie Sister, if she reape
Sad discontent, tis nones but her owne fault,
I knew the passages twixt her and Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Sister, I wonder you will name a man,
I thinke not on, he was no match for mee,
Why de'e blame me, that should rather blame
Your wandering eie, to loue a man lou'd me,

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Well tis too late now to expostulate.
But my poore little Kate, where is thy man?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Lost, lost in troth, to morrow I shall heare,
I make account hee's gone some fiue yeares voyage,
Till this disgrace of ours be ouer-blowne,
and for my Captaine Powts, by this time hee
Is ten mile on the Riuer toward Graues end.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Wordly, with two with Torches and Cudgels.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Stand you two there, Sirrha go you with me.
Why how now Girles heere still, what & your Ladyship?
Away, away, I say, go take your places.
Some Torches for my Ladie.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: You Sirrha, Exeunt Bell. Lucida, Kate.
Is my ladie Ninnie awake yet?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir, she is awake, but she is scant sober, the first thing she cal'd for, was her Aqua vitae bottle.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Who is with her?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The good Sir Innocent, and her Gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Go tell em I desire their Companie,
The Maske staies on em say, and de'e heare,
The sides of one a'th Chaire's must be let out,
For her great Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Marrie shall it Sir. Exit Seruant.

div.stage: Enter Neuill, Count, Pendant, and Sir Abraham in their Masking Robes, Sir Abra: knawing on a Capons Legge.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Soule man, leaue eating now, looke, looke, you haue all dropt a your sute.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I was in loue to day, and could not eate, but heere's one knowes the case is alter'd, lend mee but a Handkerchiefe to wipe my mouth, and I ha done.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Soule, how this Rascall staies with the rest of our things.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: How now son Count, what readie M. Neuill.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: All readie, readie, onely we tarrie for our Vizards & our Caps, I put em to a knaue to doing, because I would haue em the better done.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: If you put em to a knaue, you are like to haue em the worse done.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Your wit is most actiue, I cal'd him knaue in regard of his long stay Sir, not his worke.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: But de'e heare Maist. Neuill, did you bespeake a Vizard with a most terrible countenance for me.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: A verie Diuels face, I feare nothing but that it wil fright the weomen.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: I would it would, and a huge Mustachios?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: A verie Turkes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But do you thinke he will come at all?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Oh, there he is. Speakes within,

div.stage: By your leaue, stand backe, by your leaue. Enter Scudmore like a Vizard-maker.
div.p: Nothing can be done to night, if I enter not.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Stand backe there, or Ile burne you.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: T'were but a whoorish tricke Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 ser.
sp.p: Oh Sir ist you, Hart you'le be kild.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Marry God forbid Sir.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Pray forbeare, let me speake to him, Oh you vse vs verie well.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: In good Faith, I haue beene so troubled about this Gentlemans scuruie face (I take it) tis wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Well, are you fitted now.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Fitted at all points.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Where are the Caps.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Heere Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Let me see mine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come helpe me on with mine.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: This a rare face to fright the Maids i'th Countrey, heere now Ile pin my purse, come helpe me on.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: So, so, away, mine being on Ile follow you.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Pray make hast. Exeunt S. Iohn, Count, Pen.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: So that doores fast, and they are busied. S. Abra.
About their charge: on with this Robe of mine,
This Vizard and this Cap; helpe me a litle. Change habit.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: At first Change I must tell her who I am?

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Right, tis agree'd, I (leading of the Maske,)
Should dance with Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: And at the second, I come away with her, & leaue them dancing, and shall finde you at the backe doore.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: The rest
That followes, is digested in my breast.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What would you do? Stand backe,
Vnlesse you can eate Torches.

div.stage: Enter Count, Pend: Sir Abrahm in their Masking robes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Come, come, away for shame.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Tis such a tedious rascall. So ha we'e.

div.stage: Exeunt Maskers.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Thou hast wel fitted em, though thou mad'st em stay.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: I forbid any man to mend em Sir, good night vnto your worship.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Alas Sir, I haue another to set foorth
This very night: By your leaue my Maisters.

div.stage: Exit Neuill through them.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: By your leaue, by your leaue, you'l let a man go out?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Now go with me, and let all in that will.

div.stage: Exit Sir Iohn with them, & ran in three or foure.
Enter 2. or 3. setting 3. or 4. Chaires, & 4 or 5. stooles.

Loud Musicke, in which time, enter Sir Iohn Worldly, Sir Innocent, Bellafront, Lucida, Kate, my Lady Ninnie, Mrs. Wagtaile, they seate themselues, Lady Ninnie offers at two or three Chaires; at last finds the great one: they point at her and laugh. Assoone, as she is set, she drinkes of hir bowle, the Musicke playes, and they enter.

After one straine of the Musicke, Scudmore takes Bellafront, who seemes vnwilling to dance, Count takes Lucida, Pendant Kate, Sir Abraham. Mistris Wagtaile, Scudmore as they stand, the other Courting too, whispers as followes.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I am your Scudmore. Soft Musicke.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: By heauen I am,
Be rul'd by me in all things.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Euen to death.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Sfut did you not know me by my purse?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I should ne're haue knowne you by that, for you weare it on your head, and other folkes in their pockets.

sp.speaker: La: Nin.
sp.p: Which is my Lord I pray?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: The second man
Young Neuill leads.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: And where's Sir. Abraham?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: He with the terrible visage.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.l: Now out vpon him to disfigure himselfe so,
And t'were not for my bottle, I should swound.

div.stage: Musick, & they dance, the second strain, in which Scudm: goes away with her.

sp.speaker: Om. Spect.
sp.p: Good verie good.

div.stage: The other foure dance, another straine, honor and end.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But where's the Bride and Neuill?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Ware trickes.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Oh, there they come, it was their parts to do so

div.stage: Enter Scudmore vnvizarded, Bellafront with Pistols, and the right Parson.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This Neuill, this is Scudmore.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But heere's my Ladie,

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: No my Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Zoones Treason, I smell powder.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: In short know, that I am married to this Gent.
To whom I was contracted long ago:
This Priest the inuiolable knot hath ty'de,
What ease I finde being vn-Ladifyed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What Riddle's this?

sp.speaker: S. Inno.
sp.p: Ware the last Statute of two Husbands.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Bellafront, pish.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This is the verie Priest that married me,
Is it not Sister?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: No.

div.stage: Enter Neuill like the parson too.

sp.speaker: Abra
sp.l: Lord blesse vs heere is coniuring,
Lend me your Aqua-vitae bottle good Mother.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Hoy-day, the worldes turn'd vp side downe, I haue heard and seene two or three Benifices to one Priest, or more, But two Priests to one Benefice, ne're before.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Married not you the Earle?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bonafide, no.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: You did then?

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I haue the Priuiledge then.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Right, you were married first.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Sir Iohn you doate,
This is a Deuill in a Parsons coate.

div.stage: Neuil puts off the Priests Weeds, & has a Diuels robe vnder.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: A prettie Emblem.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.l: Who married her, or would haue caus'd hir marry
To any man but this, no better was,
Let circumstances be examined,
Yet heere's one more, and now I hope you all,
Perceiue my marrying not Cannon call.

div.stage: Slips off his Diuels weedes.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Neuill, whoop.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hart, what a deale a Knauery a Priests cloake can hide, if it be not one of the honestest friendliest Coozenages that ere I saw, I am no Lord.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Life, I am not married then in earnest.

sp.speaker: Neu.
sp.p: So Mistris Kate, I kept you for my self.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: It boots not to be angry.

sp.speaker: S. In. La.
sp.p: No faith Sir Iohn.

div.stage: Enter Strange with Powts on his backe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Whether will you go with your Calfe on your backe Sir.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Now more knauerie yet.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Prethee forbeare, or I shall do thee mischiefe: By your leaue, heere's some sad to your merriment: know you this Captaine?

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Yes verie well.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Oh Sister, heere's the Villaine slander'd me.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: You see he cannot stand to't.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Is he hurt in the arme too?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Why then by Gods-lid thou art a base Rogue, I knew I should liue to tell thee so.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: Sir Abraham I say.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Heauen is iust.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What a Rogue are you, is this the Surgeon you would carry me to?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Confesse your slander, and I will I sweare.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Nay tis no matter, Ile crie quittance with you,
Forgiue me Mrs. Kate, and know all people
I li'de not with her, but beli'de her once,
And to my recantation, that same Souldier
Enforc'd my hand. They all looke on the Paper.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Yes, heere tis Mistris Kate.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I see now how I am cheated, loue him well,
He has redeem'd your honor with his sword.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: But where is Strange my Sonne, oh were he heer He should be married new to make all sure.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Oh my Diuining Spirit, hee's gone to Sea.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This cunning in her is exceeding good,
Your Sonne, your husband, Strange is murther'd.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Peace, peace, for Heauens sake peace,
Come Sir, Ile carrre you to a Surgeon,
Heer's Gold to stop thy throat, for God-sake peace.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sirra, you haue brought mee to a Surgeon alreadie, Ile be euen with you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Of all men liuing I could marrie thee,
Were not my heart giuen to another man,
Sir you did speake of Strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: These women are as craftie as the Diuell,
Yes, I did speake of him, Sir Iohn, my Lord,
Know Strange is murther'd by that Villaines hand,
And by his wifes consent.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: God forbid.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Search presently the Closset and the Vault,
There you shall finde his bodie, tis too true,
The reason all may gesse, her husband wanting
Spirit to do on me what he hath done,
In hope to marrie her, he hath murther'd him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: To marrie me, no villaine I do hate him
On this report, worse then I do thy selfe,
And may the plagues and Tortures of a Land
Ceize me, if this be not an Innocent hand.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Fore-God tis most like truth, son Scudmore pray
Looke to this fellow, Gentlemen assist,
Torches, some Torches, Ile go search my selfe,

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: I will assist you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But I pray Sir how came you vnto this knowledge

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: From his mouth.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.l: Ile saue your labor, and discouer all:
Thou periur'd villaine, didst not sweare thou wouldst not discouer me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I but swore in iest.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Nay but remember thou didst wish Strange liuing
If euer thou didst tell, Sir all is true,
And would my punishment would ease my Conscience.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: To New-gate with him hence, take her along,
Out Murtherers, whoore thou art no child of mine,
Fetch Constable and Officers, Away.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Sir do but heare me speake.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.p: Fetch Officers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Go fetch a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Stra,
sp.p: Sir, you are then too violent, I will baile her.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Oh my deere Strange. Discouers himselfe.

sp.speaker: World,
sp.p: My Sonne.

sp.speaker: Scud. Luci. Bell.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Yong Strange.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hart, I was neuer sicke before, helpe me now to a
Surgeon, or I shall swoon instantly. As 2 leads him he speaks
Thou wer't borne a Roman-Citizen, fare thee well,
And farewell loue, and weomen, ye diseases,
My horse and sword shall be my Mistresses,
My Horse Ile court, my sword shall lye with me. Exit

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: The way to cure lust, is to bleed I see.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tell him al Scudmore, whilst I go a woing again, Sir Iohn will you go along, and my two worshipful Elders, I pray be you witnesses, Priest goe Neu. Scud. Bell. Stra. Kate. Whispers in one part. Pend. Sir Abra. & Wag. in another .not you away, Hart I haue so ruminated on a Wife, that I must haue one this night, or I shal run proud. Mistris Lucida, you did once loue mee, if you doo still, no more words, but giue me your hand, why are ye doubtfull?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Nere looke vpon me M. Lucida, Time was, Time is, and Times past, Ile none of you now, I am other-wise prouided.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: Well spoken Brazen head, now or neuer Sir Abraham.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Then first as dutie binds, I craue consent
Of my two parents deere: If I, say so;
If not, Ile ha her, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: How. how.

sp.speaker: La. Nin.
sp.p: I hope you will not

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Mam, I am resolu'd, you haue a humour of your Aqua-vitae bottle, why shoulde not I haue a humour in a wife?

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: An old man were a fitter match for her,
He would make much of her.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Much on her, I know not what ye call much making on her, I am sure I haue made two on her.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: And that an old man cannot do I hope.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Oh thou beyond Lawrence of Lancashire.

sp.speaker: S. In.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Speake not in vaine, I am to sure to change,
For hand and heart are sure,
Ecce signum, and this haue I done, and neuer lay with hir

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: Nay, then tis too late,
Tis sure, Tis vane to crosse the will of Fate.

sp.speaker: Sir In. La.
sp.p: Well, wel, God blesse you. Ab & Wag kneel

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Thankes reuerend couple, and God blesse withall
The little Ninnie that heerein doth spraule,
Parson you shall dispatch vs presently:
Lord how soberly you stand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Now truly I could nere stand drunke in my life.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Strange and most fortunate, wee must haue a new Tucke then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is it a match?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Tis done.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then Bacchus squeeze Grapes with a plenteous hand.
Parson you'le take some paines with vs to night;
Come Brothers come, flye Willow to the woods,
And like the Sea, for healths let's drinke whole floods.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I consecrate my deed vnto ths Cittie,
And hope to liue my selfe, to see the day,
It shall be shewne to people in a play.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: And may all true loue haue like happie end,
Women forgiue me; Men, admire my Friend.

sp.speaker: World.
sp.l: On Parson on, and Boy out-voice the Musicke,
Ne're was so much (what cannot heauenly powers,)
Done and vndone, and done in twelue short howers.

div.stage: Exeunt.
